results.title: Max floating to songs
results.brief_description: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past & present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

Social media users across the internet have also used special effects programs to show themselves levitating, or running out of the Upside Down from Vecna, often to their favourite songs, which they’ve edited into the visuals. This has allowed the scene to spawn numerous meme templates.

The personal element of the narrative - that your favourite song can save you from evil - and the nostalgia of the series lends itself to users contributing their own songs (and associated emotions) to the visuals, creating a personal but collective, shareable experience.

Another prominent meme created from Stranger Things 4 relies on sound. Before claiming his victims, Vecna makes them hallucinate a ticking grandfather clock (among other things) and its ominous chime (used to great effect in horror movies forever) has become an eerie indicator that he’s coming for you. Naturally, TikTokers have appropriated the sound for comedic effect. Know Your Meme traces the first use of it to user @marcusbtv, who hears it in a skit about gaming, removes one headphone and says “Nope….. not getting me”, before going back to playing.

It’s now been repurposed and reused across the internet, with users often engaging with an invisible clock (they’re hallucinating) or even Big Ben.
description_for_label: Stranger Things has introduced Zoomers to another 80s icon: pop star Kate Bush. In season four, Max (Sadie Sink) is saved from villain Vecna’s spell by her friends playing Bush’s “Running Up That Hill”. Not only did the scene shoot the song into Billboard’s top 10 for the first time in 37 years, it’s been adopted by internet users who’ve wondered what song would save them. One Twitter account tried answer that question by remixing contemporary songs into the scene, showing how online ingenuity can bridge the cultural past and present while allowing viewers to participate in moving image making.

details.label: Curatorial section

results.title: Random guy welcomes American protagonist
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @paharikawa's TikTok post
results.brief_description: TikTokker, Aslan Pahari, satirical take on the depiction of non-white characters in mainstream films
results.description: Hollywood has a long history of perpetuating stereotypes and appropriating cultures. Aslan Pahari – known for his satirical anthropological content – skewers the noble and wise Middle Eastern guide who typically leads American ‘heroes’ through supposedly ‘exotic’ lands. By combining tired tropes of Arabic culture – sand dunes, ‘wobbly air’, ‘traditional’ singing – he exposes Hollywood’s uniformed attitude towards non-white characters. Recently, Arabic and Islamic imagery and language was appropriated in Dune (2021), yet the film featured no Middle Eastern or North African actors. By including videos from other users calling out stereotypes, Pahari also demonstrates there’s no single way to represent a people or culture.
description_for_label: Hollywood has a long history of perpetuating stereotypes and appropriating cultures. Here, Aslan Pahari skewers the noble and wise guide in supposedly ‘exotic’ locales. By combining tired cinema tropes of Arab culture, he exposes Hollywood’s uniformed attitude towards non-white characters. Recently, Arabic imagery and language was appropriated in Dune (2021), yet the film featured no Middle Eastern or North African actors. Pahari also demonstrates there’s no single way to represent a people or culture by including videos from other users lampooning stereotypes.

results.title: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.brief_description: Trans actress and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.
results.title_for_label: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq

results.title: Only 3000 BC kids remember
results.brief_description: Tiktok can be educational - but not in the way you might think. Information spreads not just through researched videos, but also levity, memes, and irreverent, lo-fi video content that entertain and provoke curiosity. Questions like ‘What is a phrase that someone born after 2000 wouldn’t understand’ usually garner stitched video responses from people enthusiastically reminiscing about ‘the good old days.’ Here instead, linguist Arum Natzorkhang pokes fun at the trend by responding in Proto-Indo-European, a reconstructed language which is hypothesised to be the common ancestor to all Indo-European languages.
results.description:

results.title: Ukraine wins Eurovision
results.brief_description: Watch the moment that the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest winner was announced. A profound moment for Ukraine amidst the current political climate across the war-torn nation, as reflected by Kalush Orchestra band mate’s acceptance speech states; “This victory is for every Ukrainian!” The six-member band received special permission to leave the country to represent Ukraine.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

“This victory is for every Ukranian!” Kalush Orchestra declared when they won the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest with ‘Stefania’. The folk-rap group received special permission to travel to the competition in Turin, Italy from war-torn Ukraine. Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy congratulated the band via the Telegram messaging app. Since Russia invaded Ukraine 13 weeks ago, Zelenskyy has harnessed the power of social media to spread a message of defiance, appearing in low-fi broadcasts from his phone, often in military fatigues, to condemn the invasion and rally international support. His recorded messages have also been incorporated into other competitions and award shows, including the Grammys and Oscars.
description_for_label: “This victory is for every Ukranian!” Kalush Orchestra declared when they won the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest with ‘Stefania’. The folk-rap group received special permission to travel to the competition in Turin, Italy from war-torn Ukraine. Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy congratulated the band via the Telegram messaging app. Since Russia invaded Ukraine 13 weeks ago, Zelenskyy has harnessed the power of social media to spread a message of defiance, appearing in low-fi broadcasts from his phone, often in military fatigues, to condemn the invasion and rally international support.

results.title: I don't care what the Bible says
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @theyoungturks' TikTok account
results.brief_description: On November 5, 2018, Ana Kasparian delivered an impassioned response to American conservatives justifying their denial of women’s reproductive freedoms based on their Christian faith. On May 4 2022, when leaked documents foreshadowed the overturning of Roe v Wade – which enshrines the right to abortion in the US Constitution – the viral clip resurfaced, gaining over 101k retweets, 8,613 quote tweets and over 321k likes on just one Twitter account, demonstrating how viral content can resurface and resonate again years after its original publication. Attacks on women’s body autonomy, sadly, go back far further than 2018.
results.title_for_label: I don’t care what the Bible says
results.description:

results.title: The creative power of TikTok duets
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @vixey_co18 Tiktok video
results.brief_description: Tiktok user @KateyLorrell had humble aspirations for her now-famous video: “just trying to show my fit off, but the good lord had other plans, ” she wrote in the caption of a video of her tripping in her room. Other plans indeed: her spill now has millions of views through Tiktok ‘duets’, a feature which allows users to repost a video alongside a video accompaniment of their own, making comedy out of her (minor) misfortune.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

results.title: Audiences left laughing at bad CGI
results.brief_description: Streaming site Hulu’s long awaiting movie Death on the Nile has gone viral as viewers question the quality of the CGI. Based on an Agatha Christie novel, the murder mystery is set in 1930s Egypt but was predominately shot in the UK. Clips of the worst offending scene have been shared online and retweeted almost 9,000 times, with viewers likening the special effects to low budget productions of the 1990s. Some defended its use, explaining that it was made at the height of the pandemic when people couldn’t travel, while others wondered if it was a ‘stylistic nod’ to the sound stages of Old Hollywood.

results.title: #MorbiusSweep
results.material_description: Digital Screen Recording of @@Rick42069's twitter feed
results.brief_description: MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This particular tweet is packed full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as Director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This tweet mixes well-known memes full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”, and satirically highlights how fandoms attempt to hijack critical responses by flooding Rotten Tomatoes with disingenuous reviews, laying bare the intersection between internet hype and movie success.
description_for_label: #MorbiusSweep refers to a series of parody memes celebrating the 2022 superhero film Morbius as a massive commercial and critical success, despite the tepid response from the public. This tweet mixes well-known memes full of faked references to fan and critical touchpoints, such as director Martin Scorsese’s much publicised view that “Superhero films are not cinema”, and satirically highlights how fandoms attempt to hijack critical responses by flooding Rotten Tomatoes with disingenuous reviews, laying bare the intersection between internet hype and movie success.

results.title: The Oscars slap
results.brief_description: There are no winners in this Academy Award moment. Even those who took home Oscars had their achievement overshadowed by Will Smith’s startling assault on Chris Rock. When the internet should’ve been buzzing about Troy Kotsur winning the second Oscar awarded to a Deaf performer, or Jane Campion being only the third woman to win for Best Director, it was instead saturated by hot takes, memes and outrage – either for or against Rock’s joke or Smith’s reaction – in an ongoing feedback loop between broadcaster, viewer and meme-maker, which played out in real time during the ceremony.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

There are no winners in this Academy Award moment. Even those who took home Oscars had their achievement overshadowed by Will Smith’s startling assault on Chris Rock. When the internet should’ve been buzzing about Troy Kotsur winning the second Oscar awarded to a Deaf performer, Ariana DeBose being the first openly queer woman of colour to take one home, or Jane Campion being only the third woman to win for Best Director, it was instead saturated by hot takes, memes and outrage – either for or against Rock’s joke or Smith’s reaction – in an ongoing feedback loop between broadcaster, viewer and meme-maker, which played out in real time during the ceremony.
description_for_label: There are no winners in this Academy Award moment. Even those who took home Oscars had their achievement overshadowed by Will Smith’s startling assault on Chris Rock. When the internet should’ve been buzzing about Troy Kotsur winning the second Oscar awarded to a Deaf performer, or Jane Campion being only the third woman to win for Best Director, it was instead saturated by hot takes, memes and outrage – either for or against Rock’s joke or Smith’s reaction – in an ongoing feedback loop between broadcaster, viewer and meme-maker, which played out in real time during the ceremony.
